We are a Mombasa website design company, digital marketing agency, social media, and PR agency in one super-creative blender. Digital Marketing Kenya brand tenders and marketing mixologists always serve up unique Website designs coded with today’s modern technologies, social media campaigns, SEO improvements, and revenue-driving marketing strategies for sales leads and customer acquisition. Check out our latest concoctions.

Designing websites have been our bread and butter since 2018, and we’ve been pushing web design boundaries since. Over the years we’ve developed a process that helps us efficiently design websites that capture your audience’s attention and guide them down the conversion funnel.

We meticulously develop adaptable, mobile responsive websites designed that are simple to update and customized for each client’s specific needs. Additionally, we’ve helped our clients develop custom plugins to streamline content updates and easily track statistics, problems, users, actions, and more.

We continue to work with our clients post-launch on digital marketing efforts, web design changes, development improvements, or simply keeping their website up-to-date with the latest browser and security updates if requested.

 

If you landed on this SEO page, you most likely did a Google search for Mombasa SEO You found A Digital Marketing Kenya because we practice what we preach and understand the most important ranking factors on Google.  With our custom approach to SEO, Google ranks us first and we offer the same service for your business.  Contact us today for a free SEO audit and an in-person consultation.

post_content: We understand the reasons why you might resist building a website for on of your business: “I’m not tech-savvy”, “they’re too expensive”, “I don’t have the time”, or the infamous “I have enough business and I don’t need one”. The reality is, you don’t need to be tech-savvy, getting a professional website for your business can be cheap and easy, and to make it even simpler for you – not having a website is costing you time and money. Check this out… 81% of people research a business or service on the internet before making a purchase decision. That’s 25.92 million people searching for businesses online. Yet, 46% of business owners listed “Business currently doesn’t need one” as their #1 reason for not having a website. We’re not statisticians
post_title: but we can see that there’s a glaring disconnect here.

ID: Why You Need a Website No Matter Your Industry.
1. Having a website will attract new customers to your business and make you more money.

Your website is your number one marketing asset because we live in a digital age. People spend on average 23.6 hours online per week and are on their mobile devices for up to five hours per day. By now
post_author: consumers expect companies to have an online presence (including a website) and will consider a company that DOESN’T have one as less professional.

ID: We like this stat so much
post_author: we’re mentioning it twice:  81% of people research a business or service online before making a purchase decision. If you don’t have a website
post_date: you have no chance of capturing a share of this market.

ID: Your website can be available 24/7/365 even when you’re not. A website acts as your “always-on” business advocate during and outside of office hours.
Websites help you convert more of your existing referrals because most people still do their research and stack you against your competitors.
2.  Add instant credibility to your business simply by having a website.
The 21st-century consumer is skeptic; in fact
post_author: 56% of people stated that they won’t trust a business without a website. Having a good website instantly boosts your credibility as a legitimate business.
and websites allow you to make a very strong impression with a well-designed introduction for your business.

ID: A website can help showcase your expertise and better position your business. A website can be your number one tool for standing out in a crowd.

post_author: or as expensive
post_date: as you think.

ID: You don’t need to be tech-savvy to get a website. Many web development companies have very simple signup processes which make the process quick and painless for you.
It can be very cost-effective. Websites offer a better return on investment than any other form of advertising. If you’re planning to market your business
post_author: a website should be your priority.

ID: Over time the relatively low investment of getting a business website will pay dividends by driving you new customers and building your brand. <strong><a href=\"https://turbotax.intuit.ca/tax-resources/business-owner-tax/computer-software-deductions-for-business-owners.jsp\">Plus
post_author: it’s a legitimate business expense and a tax write off.

ID: 4.  Having a website will end up saving you time.

post_author: taking calls
post_date: or sending out proposals – communicating with potential customers takes time. Your website can save you that time by providing answers to common customer questions and inquiries. What does this mean for you? You can spend your time doing more valuable things.

ID: 5. Position yourself and stay in control of your brand.
A website acts as a platform for your messaging and shapes the online perception of your business in a way that your social media channels cannot provide.
The platform allows you to position yourself in the market to get the exact type of customers you’re looking for.
Many business owners have been reviewed online
post_author: sometimes unknowingly and/or negatively. How does this affect you? <a href=\"https://www.salesforce.com/ca/blog/2015/03/customer-reviews.html\">79% of users who read online reviews
post_date: believe them. Combat that negativity by posting your positive testimonials.

ID: Avoid 5 common mistakes in Website Design

Flash animation certainly has its place in website design – but it's typically not on the home page of your small business Web design. Customers arrive at your website expecting to find helpful information about the products and services that interest them – not a slowly unfolding display of digital animation. Use flash wisely – and sparingly – in your professional Web design.
•  Don't Strain the Eye.Keeping website design simple can save you – and your customers – from headaches. Use a tried-and-true font style
post_author: such as Arial
post_date: that's sans-serif and proven to be readable. The background is another area of concern for professional Web design. Using patterned backgrounds or placing colored type against a black background may cause users to seek someone else's more pleasing website design.

ID: The use of navigation in professional Web design is akin to the use of GPS on a road trip. Use it wisely and visitors will arrive at the desired destination - and even enjoy themselves along the way. Resist the urge to get too creative with this aspect of your small business Web design – a clean navigation panel is a user's best resource. When you hide website design navigation in fancy flash animation or images
post_author: your customers will get lost – and lose interest.

ID: When your website design is full of graphics and images
post_author: it requires a greater amount of bandwidth. This increased bandwidth takes longer for the user to download. In the time it takes for your website design to load
post_date: your customer may very well decide it's not worth the wait. Try not to forget the people using dial-up or mobile Internet connection. Use the graphics and images that are necessary for your small business Web design and save the rest for your portfolio.

ID: Everyone has come across a small business Web design that seems to include everything but the proverbial kitchen sink. Cluttered website design overwhelms your site's visitors and can make your business appear unprofessional. A disorganized website design tends to reflect poorly on the very business it is supposed to promote
post_author: while a professional Web design speaks volumes about your attention to detail.

ID: Your website design will become the \"face\" of your business
post_author: so you'll need a professional Web design that not only turns customers' heads but also keeps them interested. Follow the simple guidelines of small business Web design and you'll see the beauty in more positive visitor experience.
DO I NEED A WEBSITE FOR MY SMALL BUSINESS? YES, YOU DO. HERE ARE 5 REASONS WHY.
post_content: closed

ID: Avoid 5 common mistakes in Website Design

Flash animation certainly has its place in website design – but it's typically not on the home page of your small business Web design. Customers arrive at your website expecting to find helpful information about the products and services that interest them – not a slowly unfolding display of digital animation. Use flash wisely – and sparingly – in your professional Web design.
Keeping website design simple can save you – and your customers – from headaches. Use a tried-and-true font style
post_author: such as Arial
post_date: that's sans-serif and proven to be readable. The background is another area of concern for professional Web design. Using patterned backgrounds or placing colored type against a black background may cause users to seek someone else's more pleasing website design.

ID: The use of navigation in professional Web design is akin to the use of GPS on a road trip. Use it wisely and visitors will arrive at the desired destination - and even enjoy themselves along the way. Resist the urge to get too creative with this aspect of your small business Web design – a clean navigation panel is a user's best resource. When you hide website design navigation in fancy flash animation or images
post_author: your customers will get lost – and lose interest.

ID: When your website design is full of graphics and images
post_author: it requires a greater amount of bandwidth. This increased bandwidth takes longer for the user to download. In the time it takes for your website design to load
post_date: your customer may very well decide it's not worth the wait. Try not to forget the people using dial-up or mobile Internet connection. Use the graphics and images that are necessary for your small business Web design and save the rest for your portfolio.

ID: Everyone has come across a small business Web design that seems to include everything but the proverbial kitchen sink. Cluttered website design overwhelms your site's visitors and can make your business appear unprofessional. A disorganized website design tends to reflect poorly on the very business it is supposed to promote
post_author: while a professional Web design speaks volumes about your attention to detail.

ID: Your website design will become the \"face\" of your business
post_author: so you'll need a professional Web design that not only turns customers' heads but also keeps them interested. Follow the simple guidelines of small business Web design and you'll see the beauty in more positive visitor experience.

post_date: https://www.digitalmarketingkenya.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/CTA-post-150x150.png 150w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 539px) 100vw
post_content: Post

Millions of businesses, big and small, connect with people on Facebook. 2.5 billion people use Facebook every month to connect with friends and family and to discover things that matter. Find new customers and build lasting relationships with them.

Who employs Facebook Marketing

Featuring nearly a billion potential customers, every business should be using Facebook. It is at least as essential as having a business web page—and actually much easier to create. Whether you represent a big brand or a small business employing only a handful of people, you can bet that some portion of your customers are already on Facebook. Commonly, Facebook marketing is used by:

post_author: electronics
post_date: home goods
post_date_gmt: restaurants—nearly any kind of brand can be promoted through Facebook
post_content: turning passive customers into active fans who follow news of promotions and developments
post_title: and who share with their own friends.

ID: • Local businesses. Whether a business is family-owned
post_author: or a franchise of a larger company
post_date: a Facebook page can be used to turn a local customer base into a fan base that more commonly visits your store.

post_author: celebrities
post_date: authors
post_date_gmt: syndicated columnists—anybody who makes their money through being known wants to be known by as many people as they can on Facebook.

post_author: political groups
post_date: and public service campaigns can all leverage the natural sharing capabilities of Facebook.

ID: For what kinds of customers are Facebook marketing effective?
While originally marketed to college students
post_author: Facebook has expanded well beyond that demographic.  More than half of all users are in the 18-34 age range
post_date: and slightly more than half of United States users are women. In the United States
post_date_gmt: about half of all user profiles are accessed through mobile devices as well as through computers. Due to its considerable amount of users
post_content: there is a wide variety of market segments that can be reached on Facebook
post_title: and an active fan base for nearly any niche.

ID: A more helpful question about Facebook customers would be: When is Facebook marketing most effective? For brand and company pages
post_author: posts made in the morning attract more comments than posts made in the afternoon. Consumers at home may check Facebook at any time during the day (the peak traffic period is around 3:00 in the afternoon). However
post_date: working or school-going consumers commonly check Facebook before and after work/school; therefore
post_date_gmt: only posting during the 9-5 business day misses a lot of opportunities.

ID: How is a Facebook marketing campaign developed?
Facebook pages are often linked to company web pages elsewhere on the Internet; therefore
post_author: it’s often a good idea to use some of the same information in both places
post_date: in order to maintain familiarity. A business page can be searched for as soon as it is up
post_content: you cannot invite friends through it. Business pages do not get “friends
post_title: ” they get “fans”—and that distinction does make a difference.

ID: To create an initial seed for the fan base
post_author: each member of the marketing team should begin by liking the business page on their own personal profiles; all employees
post_date: in fact
post_date_gmt: should be encouraged to join in. When an individual likes a page
post_content: Facebook immediately posts (read: advertisers) this event to their profile—and this activity can be seen by every one of their friends. “Joe Smith likes [this brand].” The word begins to spread.

ID: A variety of different applications can be added to a Facebook page. Downloading various apps can allow you to:
• connect your YouTube channel to your Facebook page.
<li>coordinate your Facebook page with your company blog
post_author: or with your Twitter account

ID: • provide visitors a means of signing up for your newsletter through your Facebook page
Every Facebook user who likes a page will get to see any content a business posts
post_author: and be notified of posts through their news feed. If they are engaged by that content
post_date: they may comment on it
post_date_gmt: or like that item; and “Joe Smith commented on [this brand’s] status update” appears on all of their friends’ news feeds. Additionally
post_content: they may share this content
post_excerpt: read: advertise) the entire content to their own profiles
post_status: and notify their friends to come to look. The company's task
ping_status: is to encourage this process as much as possible.

ID: The most important aspect of Facebook marketing is the consistency of communication. Creating a Facebook page and then leaving it alone will net a business nothing. To attract fans
post_author: a business should regularly post new content in a variety of different formats
post_date: so that more people will see and share the page. Content can announce upcoming promotions
post_content: share fun facts
post_title: provide incentive codes for discounts on products and services
post_excerpt: and anything else that will catch the interest of fans.

ID: Given the way Facebook’s news feed works
post_author: the recency of a post is a major factor in organizing what a user sees. The average user has more than 130 friends and maybe a fan of several brands
post_date: personalities
post_date_gmt: and organizations. When he or she logs in
post_content: there is no way to instantly see activity from every one of those sources.

ID: The news feed shows them posts from their friends/etc. they interact with most
post_author: and which are more recent. Therefore
post_date: a company's post is only likely to be visible on their fans’ news feeds for about three hours after they post it. Furthermore
post_date_gmt: depending upon the time of day they post
post_content: it is likely to be seen by entirely different portions of their fan base.

ID: In addition to varied content and formating
post_author: posts should invite customers to interact and respond. Businesses should present consistent calls to action
post_date: which can be as simple as “watch this
post_content: ” or “share this.\" Additionally
post_title: businesses can invite participation through contests and polls (which are also a way to collect market research). Such low-commitment investments encourage familiarity and affinity in their customer base.

ID: This positive relationship can be further promoted by maintaining two-way communication. In other words
post_author: when fans post a comment on content
post_date: businesses should respond. How much they respond will depend upon how many fans comment
post_date_gmt: and how much time they can commit to Facebook marketing; but the more any particular fan interacts with a page
post_content: the more likely he or she is to buy."

Your website is the most important marketing tool you have. It's the hub of your inbound marketing strategy and it's the number one thing your prospects want to explore before making a purchase. Now that most businesses understand the value of inbound marketing, business websites overall are getting better. They're faster, sleeker, mobile-friendly, and more useful -- which is great for the consumer, but makes the job of a marketer that much harder. In this environment, we're all forced to step our game up if we want to stand out from our competitors, which leads us to the inevitable project all modern businesses will face at one point or another -- a website redesign. The cost of a website redesign in Nairobi can vary tremendously from as low as a Kes. 5000 if you do it yourself to Kes. 10ks  for an advanced, custom-built website. Since businesses often have no idea how much they should pay for a website redesign and what to expect for their money, we've decided to answer that question once and for all. Not sure if you actually need a website redesign? Submit your site for the chance to appear on our upcoming live website critique, Website Throwdown, and we'll tear apart your design, UX, content, and more!

The Cost of Doing Your Own Website Redesign

The building or redesigning a website yourself is the cheapest option. The real cost of doing a website redesign yourself is the time and hassle required. Generally speaking, the less money you spend, the more time and hassle you can expect to deal with to get the site how you want it -- and it still won't be exactly how you want it because custom work requires the ability to code. New startups with limited budgets will have to start small. ThemeForest offers tons of affordable website themes (especially for WordPress) to choose from that usually cost around $30 to $100. Functionality, performance, and ease-of-use from those themes vary widely. Be sure to look for a theme that's received a lot of positive reviews, has a strong track record, and allows you to make edits without any technical skill. Another popular option is the Genesis Framework by StudioPress. The Genesis Framework is essentially the back-end of your website that you install on WordPress, allowing you to create content and edit the visual features of your theme with ease. Once you've installed the framework, you'll install a theme, which is basically the aesthetic design of your website. Their framework is a huge step up from the average, lower-priced theme on the market. Their themes look great, they're mobile-friendly, optimized for search engines, and easy to use. Take a look at their themes here -- a lot of them will look familiar because tons of websites use them. The framework + theme ranges from kes. 10,000 to kes. 13,000.
post_title: Affordable Web design cost In Nairobi

Your website is the most important marketing tool you have. It's the hub of your inbound marketing strategy and it's the number one thing your prospects want to explore before making a purchase. Now that most businesses understand the value of inbound marketing, business websites overall are getting better. They're faster, sleeker, mobile-friendly, and more useful -- which is great for the consumer, but makes the job of a marketer that much harder. In this environment, we're all forced to step our game up if we want to stand out from our competitors, which leads us to the inevitable project all modern businesses will face at one point or another -- a website redesign. The cost of a website redesign in Nairobi can vary tremendously from as low as a Kes. 5000 if you do it yourself to Kes. 10ks  for an advanced, custom-built website. Since businesses often have no idea how much they should pay for a website redesign and what to expect for their money, we've decided to answer that question once and for all. Not sure if you actually need a website redesign? Submit your site for the chance to appear on our upcoming live website critique, Website Throwdown, and we'll tear apart your design, UX, content, and more!

The Cost of Doing Your Own Website Redesign

The building or redesigning a website yourself is the cheapest option. The real cost of doing a website redesign yourself is the time and hassle required. Generally speaking, the less money you spend, the more time and hassle you can expect to deal with to get the site how you want it -- and it still won't be exactly how you want it because custom work requires the ability to code. New startups with limited budgets will have to start small. ThemeForest offers tons of affordable website themes (especially for WordPress) to choose from that usually cost around $30 to $100. Functionality, performance, and ease-of-use from those themes vary widely. Be sure to look for a theme that's received a lot of positive reviews, has a strong track record, and allows you to make edits without any technical skill. Another popular option is the Genesis Framework by StudioPress. The Genesis Framework is essentially the back-end of your website that you install on WordPress, allowing you to create content and edit the visual features of your theme with ease. Once you've installed the framework, you'll install a theme, which is basically the aesthetic design of your website. Their framework is a huge step up from the average, lower-priced theme on the market. Their themes look great, they're mobile-friendly, optimized for search engines, and easy to use. Take a look at their themes here -- a lot of them will look familiar because tons of websites use them. The framework + theme ranges from kes. 10,000 to kes. 13,000. However, if you're willing to spend a little bit more, and you want to use HubSpot's marketing software, there's an even better option. We recommend using HubSpot's Website Platform, which costs $300 per month. They have many customizable themes to choose from or you can build one from scratch using their drag-and-drop builder. Their Website Platform has everything you need built-in, from SEO to content management. Then you can also hire a developer later to add more custom features or to tweak the design however you want. Our website runs on the HubSpot's Website Platform and we absolutely love it! The Cost of Hiring a Freelancer for a Website Redesign
post_title: Affordable Web design cost In Nairobi

post_content: Eloquent also offers advanced subquery support, which allows you to pull information from related tables in a single query. For example, let's imagine that we have a table of flight destinations and a table of flights to destinations. The flights table contains an arrived_at a column which indicates when the flight arrived at the destination.

ID: Using the subquery functionality available to the select and addSelect methods
post_author: we can select all of the destinations and the name of the flight that most recently arrived at that destination using a single query:

ID: use App\\Destination;
use App\\Flight;
return Destination::addSelect(['last_flight' => Flight::select('name')
->whereColumn('destination_id'
post_author: 'destinations.id')

ID: ->orderBy('arrived_at'
post_author: 'desc')

ID: ->limit(1)
])->get();

post_author: the query builder's orderBy the function supports subqueries. We may use this functionality to sort all destinations based on when the last flight arrived at that destination. Again
post_date: this may be done while executing a single query against the database:

ID: return Destination::orderByDesc(
Flight::select('arrived_at')
->whereColumn('destination_id'
post_author: 'destinations.id')

ID: ->orderBy('arrived_at'
post_author: 'desc')

ID: ->limit(1)
)->get();"

post_author: 2018. Oracle VirtualBox 5.2 is the latest major release after launched by Oracle team. This version has the new feature to export VM to Oracle Cloud
post_date: Unattended guest installation
post_date_gmt: improved tools handling with more attractive icons. Oracle team also added an experimental feature for audio support for video recording. See the ChangeLog for more details.

ID: This article helps you to install VirtualBox on Ubuntu 16.04 LTS systems.
You must have logged in to your server using root or sudo privileged user. After login to your system update current packages of the system to the latest version.
Let’s import the Oracle public key to your system signed the Debian packages using the following commands.

post_author: you need to add Oracle VirtualBox PPA to Ubuntu system. You can do this by running the below command on your system.

ID: This command will add an entry to /etc/apt/sources.list at end of the file.

post_author: let’s install VirtualBox using the following commands. If you have already installed an older version of VirtualBox
post_date: Below command will update it automatically.

ID: We can use dashboard shortcuts to start VirtualBox or simply run following command from a terminal.

post_title: Making this the first true generator on the internet

post_content:
git config credential.helper 'store [<options>]'

Using this helper will store your passwords unencrypted on disk
post_title: protected only by filesystem permissions. If this is not an acceptable security tradeoff
post_status: or find a helper that integrates with secure storage provided by your operating system.

ID: Use <path> to lookup and store credentials. The file will have its filesystem permissions set to prevent other users on the system from reading it
post_author: but will not be encrypted or otherwise protected. If not specified
post_date: credentials will be searched for from ~/.git-credentials and $XDG_CONFIG_HOME/git/credentials
post_date_gmt: and credentials will be written to ~/.git-credentials if it exists
post_content: or$XDG_CONFIG_HOME/git/credentials if it exists and the former does not. See also FILES.

post_author: there are two files where git-credential-store will search for credentials in order of precedence:~/.git-credentials

ID: Second user-specific credentials file. If $XDG_CONFIG_HOME is not set or empty
post_author: $HOME/.config/git/credentials will be used. Any credentials stored in this file will not be used if ~/.git-credentials has a matching credential as well. It is a good idea not to create this file if you sometimes use older versions of Git that do not support it.
the files are read in the order given above
post_date: with the first matching credential found taking precedence over credentials found in files further down the list.

ID: Credential storage will by default write to the first existing file in the list. If none of these files exist
post_author: ~/.git-credentials will be created and written to.
matching credentials will be erased from all files.

ID: The point of this helper is to reduce the number of times you must type your username or password. For example:
The .git-credentials file is stored in plaintext. Each credential is stored on its own line as a URL like:
When Git needs authentication for a particular URL context
post_author: credential-store will consider that context a pattern to match against each entry in the credentials file. If the protocol
post_date: hostname
post_date_gmt: and username (if we already have one) match
post_content: then the password is returned to Git. See the discussion of configuration in gitcredentials[7] for more information.

post_author: Ways to remember git credentials,
post_content: closed

• LEMP stack stands for Linux, Nginx, MariaDB, and PHP. Here in LAMP stack which stands for Linux, Apache, MariaDB and PHP, all components are not tightly coupled. So by replacing Apache With Nginx, we are installing LEMP stack. This tutorial outlines how to install LEMP stack on Ubuntu 18.04.

Introduction

The LEMP software stack is a group of software that can be used to serve dynamic web pages and web applications. This is an acronym that describes a Linux operating system
post_title:
with an Nginx (pronounced like “Engine-X”) web server. The backend data is stored in the MySQL database and the dynamic processing is handled by PHP.

This guide demonstrates how to install a LEMP stack on an Ubuntu 18.04 server. The Ubuntu operating system takes care of the first requirement. We will describe how to get the rest of the components up and running.

Prerequisites

Before you complete this tutorial
post_status:
non-root user account on your server with sudo privileges. Set up this account by completing our initial server setup guide for Ubuntu 18.04.

Once you have your user available
comment_status:
you are ready to begin the steps outlined in this guide.

Step 1 – Installing the Nginx Web Server

In order to display web pages to our site visitors
ping_status: we are going to employ Nginx
post_name:
efficient web server.

All of the software used in this procedure will come from Ubuntu's default package repositories. This means we can use the apt package management suite to complete the necessary installations.

Since this is our first time using apt for this session
to_ping: start off by updating your server’s package index. Following that
pinged:
install the server:

  • sudo apt update
  • sudo apt install nginx

On Ubuntu 18.04
post_modified:
Nginx is configured to start running upon installation.

If you have the ufw firewall running
post_modified_gmt: as outlined in the initial setup guide
post_content_filtered: you will need to allow connections to Nginx. Nginx registers itself with ufw upon installation
post_parent:
so the procedure is rather straightforward.

It is recommended that you enable the most restrictive profile that will still allow the traffic you want. Since you haven't configured SSL for your server in this guide
guid:
you will only need to allow traffic on port 80.

Enable this by typing:

sudo ufw allow 'Nginx HTTP'

You can verify the change by running:

sudo ufw status

This command’s output will show that HTTP traffic is allowed:

Output

Status: active

post_author:
you can test if the server is up and running by accessing your server's domain name or public IP address in your web browser.

If you do not have a domain name pointed at your server and you do not know your server's public IP address
post_date:
you can find it by running the following command:

ip addr show eth0 | grep inet | awk '{ print $2; }' | sed 's/\\/.*$//'

This will print out a few IP addresses. You can try each of them in turn in your web browser.

As an alternative
post_date_gmt: you can check which IP address is accessible
post_content:
as viewed from other locations on the internet:

curl -4 icanhazip.com

Type the address that you receive in your web browser and it will take you to Nginx's default landing page:

http://server_domain_or_IP

If you see the above page
post_title:
you have successfully installed Nginx.

Step 2 – Installing MySQL to Manage Site Data

Now that you have a web server
post_excerpt:
you need to install MySQL (a database management system) to store and manage the data for your site.

Install MySQL by typing:

sudo apt install mysql-server

The MySQL database software is now installed
post_status:
but its configuration is not yet complete.

To secure the installation
comment_status:
MySQL comes with a script that will ask whether we want to modify some insecure defaults. Initiate the script by typing:

sudo mysql_secure_installation

This script will ask if you want to configure the VALIDATE PASSWORD PLUGIN.

Warning: Enabling this feature is something of a judgment call. If enabled
ping_status: passwords which don't match the specified criteria will be rejected by MySQL with an error. This will cause issues if you use a weak password in conjunction with software which automatically configures MySQL user credentials
post_password: such as the Ubuntu packages for phpMyAdmin. It is safe to leave validation disabled
post_name: but you should always use strong
to_ping:
unique passwords for database credentials.

Answer Y for yes
pinged:
or anything else to continue without enabling.

VALIDATE PASSWORD PLUGIN can be used to test passwords

ID: and improve security. It checks the strength of password
and allows the users to set only those passwords which are
secure enough. Would you like to setup VALIDATE PASSWORD plugin?

post_author: any other key for No:

the script will also ask you to select a level of password validation. Keep in mind that if you enter 2 – for the strongest level – you will receive errors when attempting to set any password which does not contain numbers
post_date: upper and lowercase letters
post_content:
or which is based on common dictionary words.

There are three levels of password validation policy:

post_author: numeric
post_date: mixed case

post_author: numeric
post_date: mixed case

post_author: 1 = MEDIUM and 2 = STRONG: 1

you'll be asked to submit and confirm a root password:

Please set the password for root here.

ID:
Re-enter new password:

For the rest of the questions
post_author: you should press Y and hit the ENTER key at each prompt. This will remove some anonymous users and the test database
post_date: disable remote root logins
post_date_gmt:
and load these new rules so that MySQL immediately respects the changes we have made.

Note that in Ubuntu systems running MySQL 5.7 (and later versions)
post_content: the root MySQL user is set to authenticate using the auth_socket plugin by default rather than with a password. This allows for some greater security and usability in many cases
post_title: but it can also complicate things when you need to allow an external program (e.g.
post_excerpt:
phpMyAdmin) to access the user.

If using the auth_socket plugin to access MySQL fits with your workflow
post_status: you can proceed to Step 3. If
ping_status: you prefer to use a password when connecting to MySQL as root
post_password: you will need to switch its authentication method from auth_socket to mysql_native_password. To do this
post_name:
open up the MySQL prompt from your terminal:

sudo mysql

Next
to_ping:
check which authentication method each of your MySQL user accounts use with the following command:

SELECT user

post_author: you can see that the root user does in fact authenticate using the auth_socket plugin. To configure the root account to authenticate with a password
post_date:
run the following ALTER USER command. Be sure to change password to a strong password of your choosing:

ALTER USER 'root'@'localhost' IDENTIFIED WITH mysql_native_password BY 'password';

Then
post_date_gmt:
run FLUSH PRIVILEGES which tells the server to reload the grant tables and put your new changes into effect:

FLUSH PRIVILEGES;

Check the authentication methods employed by each of your users again to confirm that root no longer authenticates using the auth_socket plugin:

SELECT user
post_content: authentication_string

ID: You can see in this example output that the root MySQL user now authenticates using a password. Once you confirm this on your own server
post_author:
you can exit the MySQL shell:

exit

Note: After configuring your root MySQL user to authenticate with a password
post_date: you'll no longer be able to access MySQL with the sudo mysql command used previously. Instead
post_date_gmt:
you must run the following:

mysql -u root -p

After entering the password you just set
post_content:
you will see the MySQL prompt.

At this point
post_title:
your database system is now set up and you can move on to installing PHP.

Step 3 – Installing PHP and Configuring Nginx to Use the PHP Processor

You now have Nginx installed to serve your pages and MySQL installed to store and manage your data. However
post_excerpt:
you still don't have anything that can generate dynamic content. This is where PHP comes into play.

Since Nginx does not contain native PHP processing like some other web servers
comment_status:
which stands for \"fastCGI process manager\". We will tell Nginx to pass PHP requests to this software for processing.

Note: Depending on your cloud provider
ping_status: you may need to add Ubuntu's universe repository
post_password: which includes free and open-source software maintained by the Ubuntu community
post_name:
before installing the php-fpm package. You can do this by typing:

sudo add-apt-repository universe

Install the php-fpm module along with an additional helper package
pinged:
which will allow PHP to communicate with your database backend. The installation will pull in the necessary PHP core files. Do this by typing:

sudo apt install php-fpm php-mysql

You now have all of the required LEMP stack components installed
post_modified:
but you still need to make a few configuration changes in order to tell Nginx to use the PHP processor for dynamic content.

This is done on the server block level (server blocks are similar to Apache's virtual hosts). To do this
post_modified_gmt:
open a new server block configuration file within the

 /etc/nginx/sites-available/ 

directory. In this example
post_content_filtered: the new server block configuration file is named example.com
post_parent:
although you can name yours whatever you’d like:

sudo nano /etc/nginx/sites-available/example.com

By editing a new server block configuration file
guid: rather than editing the default one
menu_order:
you’ll be able to easily restore the default configuration if you ever need to.

Add the following content
post_type: which was taken and slightly modified from the default server block configuration file
post_mime_type:
to your new server block configuration file:

/etc/nginx/sites-available/example.com

server {

ID:
Here’s what each of these directives and location blocks do:

listen — Defines what port Nginx will listen on. In this case
post_author: it will listen on port 80
post_date:
the default port for HTTP.

  • root — Defines the document root where the files served by the website are stored.
  • index — Configures Nginx to prioritize serving files named index.php when an index file is requested
post_date_gmt:
if they’re available.
  • server_name — Defines which server block should be used for a given request to your server. Point this directive to your server's domain name or public IP address.
  • location / — The first location block includes a try_files directive
post_content: which checks for the existence of files matching a URI request. If Nginx cannot find the appropriate file
post_title:
it will return a 404 error.
  • location ~ \\.php$ — This location block handles the actual PHP processing by pointing Nginx to the fastcgi-php.conf configuration file and the php7.2-fpm.sock file
post_excerpt:
which declares what socket is associated with php-fpm.
  • location ~ /\\.ht — The last location block deals with .htaccess files
post_status: which Nginx does not process. By adding the deny all directive
comment_status:
if any .htaccess files happen to find their way into the document root they will not be served to visitors.

After adding this content
ping_status:
save and close the file. Enable your new server block by creating a symbolic link from your new server block configuration file (in the 

/etc/nginx/sites-available/ directory) to the /etc/nginx/sites-enabled/ directory:

sudo ln -s /etc/nginx/sites-available/example.com /etc/nginx/sites-enabled/

Then
post_password:
unlink the default configuration file from the /sites-enabled/ directory:

sudo unlink /etc/nginx/sites-enabled/default

Note: If you ever need to restore the default configuration
post_name: you can do so by recreating the symbolic link
to_ping:
like this:

sudo ln -s /etc/nginx/sites-available/default /etc/nginx/sites-enabled/

Test your new configuration file for syntax errors by typing:

sudo nginx -t

If any errors are reported
pinged:
go back and recheck your file before continuing.

When you are ready
post_modified:
reload Nginx to make the necessary changes:

sudo systemctl reload nginx

This concludes the installation and configuration of your LEMP stack. However
post_modified_gmt:
it’s prudent to confirm that all of the components can communicate with one another.

Step 4 – Creating a PHP File to Test Configuration

Your LEMP stack should now be completely set up. You can test it to validate that Nginx can correctly hand .php files off to the PHP processor.

To do this
post_content_filtered:
use your text editor to create a test PHP file called info.php in your document root:

sudo nano /var/www/html/info.php

Enter the following lines into the new file. This is valid PHP code that will return information about your server:

/var/www/html/info.php

<?php

post_author:
save and close the file.

Now
post_date:
you can visit this page in your web browser by visiting your server's domain name or public IP address followed by /info.php:

http://your_server_domain_or_IP/info.php

ID:
You should see a web page that has been generated by PHP with information about your server:

If you see a page that looks like this
post_author:
you've set up PHP processing with Nginx successfully.

After verifying that Nginx renders the page correctly
post_date:
it's best to remove the file you created as it can actually give unauthorized users some hints about your configuration that may help them try to break in. You can always regenerate this file if you need it later.

For now
post_date_gmt:
remove the file by typing:

sudo rm /var/www/html/info.php

With that
post_content:
you now have a fully-configured and functioning LEMP stack on your Ubuntu 18.04 server.

Conclusion

A LEMP stack is a powerful platform that will allow you to set up and serve nearly any website or application from your server. Where are a number of next steps you could take from here. For example
post_title:
you should ensure that connections to your server are secured.

"
post_excerpt: How To Install LEMP Stack On Ubuntu 14.04, 16.04 and 18.04

ID: Step 5 — Enabling External Access for Your Regular User
Now that we have a regular user for daily use

ID: The process for configuring SSH access for your new user depends on whether your server's root account uses a password or SSH keys for authentication.
If the Root Account Uses Password Authentication
If you logged in to your root account using a password

you will be logged in. Remember

Initial Server Setup with Ubuntu 18.04
post_content: closed

When you first create a new Ubuntu 18.04 server, there are a few configuration steps that you should take early on as part of the basic setup. This will increase the security and usability of your server and will give you a solid foundation for subsequent actions.

While you can complete these steps manually
post_title: sometimes it can be easier to script the processes to save time and eliminate human error. This guide explains how to use a script to automate the steps in the initial server setup guide.

ID: What Does the Script Do?
This script is an alternative to manually running through the procedure outlined in the Ubuntu 18.04 initial server setup guide and the guide on setting up SSH keys on Ubuntu 18.04.
The following variables affect how the script is run:

• USERNAME: The name of the regular user account to create and grant sudo privileges to.
  • COPY_AUTHORIZED_KEYS_FROM_ROOT: Whether to copy the SSH key assets from the root account to the new sudo account.
  • OTHER_PUBLIC_KEYS_TO_ADD: An array of strings representing other public keys to add to the sudo-enabled account. This can optionally be used in addition to or instead of copying the keys from the root account.
You should update these variables as needed before running the script.

post_author: the following actions are performed:

ID:
• Create a regular user account with sudo privileges using the name specified by the USERNAMEvariable.
  • Configure the initial password state for the new account:
    • If the server was configured for password authentication
post_author: the original
post_date:
generated administrative password is moved from the root account to the new sudo account. The password for the root account is then locked.
  • If the server was configured for SSH key authentication
post_date_gmt:
a blank password is set for the sudoaccount.
  • The sudo user's password is marked as expired so that it must be changed upon first login.
  • The authorized_keys file from the root account is copied over to the sudo user if COPY_AUTHORIZED_KEYS_FROM_ROOT is set to true.
  • Any keys defined in OTHER_PUBLIC_KEYS_TO_ADD are added to the sudo user's authorized_keys file.
  • Password-based SSH authentication is disabled for the root user.
  • The UFW firewall is enabled with SSH connections permitted.

ID: How To Use the Script
The script can be run in two ways: by adding it to the server's user data field during creation or by logging in as root and executing it after provisioning.
When creating a Droplet on DigitalOcean
post_author: you can optionally specify user data
post_date: a script to be run during the initial server provisioning to perform additional configuration.

ID: If you are creating a Droplet from the Control Panel
post_author: you can select the User data checkbox in the Select additional options section. A text box will appear where you can paste the script:

ID: If you are creating a Droplet using the DigitalOcean API
post_author: you can pass in the script using the user_dataattribute instead.

ID: If you are creating a Droplet with the doctl command line tool
post_author: you can pass in the script using the --user-data-file option:

ID: Regardless of the method you use to add the user data
post_author: the script will be run the first time the new server boots up. You may have to wait a few minutes for the process to complete
post_date: but afterwards
post_date_gmt: you can log into your server with your sudo-enabled user for any further configuration.

ID: The first time you log in
post_author: you will be prompted to change your password. The server will terminate the current SSH session once you provide and confirm your new credentials. Afterwards
post_date: you can SSH back in again as normal.

ID: If you do not want to use user data
post_author: you can also run the script manually over SSH once the server is booted up.

ID: If you have downloaded the script to your local computer
post_author: you can pass the script directly to SSH by typing:

ID: You should now be able to log in using your sudo account for any further configuration.
If you do not have the script downloaded to your local computer
post_author: start by logging into the root account on your server:
download the raw script to the server:

ID: Inspect the script to ensure that it downloaded properly and update any variables that you wish to change:

post_author: run the script manually using bash:

ID: You should be able to log in using the sudo-enabled user to complete any further configuration.
You can find the initial server setup script in the automated-setups repository in the DigitalOcean Community GitHub organization. To copy or download the script contents directly
post_author: click the Raw button towards the top of the script
post_date: or click here to view the raw contents directly.

ID: The full contents are also included here for convenience:
# Name of the user to create and grant sudo privileges
# Whether to copy over the root user's `authorized_keys` file to the new sudo
# Additional public keys to add to the new sudo user
# Add sudo user and grant privileges
# Check whether the root account has a real password set
# Transfer auto-generated root password to user if present
# and lock the root account to password-based access
# Delete invalid password for user if using keys so that a new password
# can be set without providing a previous value
# Expire the sudo user's password immediately to force a change
# Create SSH directory for sudo user
# Copy `authorized_keys` file from root if requested
# Adjust SSH configuration ownership and permissions
# Disable root SSH login with password
# Add exception for SSH and then enable UFW firewall
Automating the initial server setup can save you a bit of time and gives you a good foundation for further configuration. If there are additional steps you'd like to take
post_author: you can either log in after the script runs to continue manually
post_date:
or append the steps to the end of the script to automate the process.

post_content:
SSH, or secure shell, is an encrypted protocol used to administer and communicate with servers. When working with an Ubuntu server, chances are you will spend most of your time in a terminal session connected to your server through SSH.

In this guide, we'll focus on setting up SSH keys for a vanilla Ubuntu 16.04 installation. SSH keys provide an easy, secure way of logging into your server and are recommended for all users.

Step 1 — Create the RSA Key Pair

ID: The first step is to create a key pair on the client machine (usually your computer):
By default ssh-keygen will create a 2048-bit RSA key pair
post_author: which is secure enough for most use cases (you may optionally pass in the -b 4096 flag to create a larger 4096-bit key).
you should see the following output:

ID: Enter file in which to save the key (/your_home/.ssh/id_rsa):
Press ENTER to save the key pair into the .ssh/ subdirectory in your home directory
post_author: or specify an alternate path.

ID: If you had previously generated an SSH key pair
post_author: you may see the following prompt:

ID: If you choose to overwrite the key on disk
post_author: you will not be able to authenticate using the previous key anymore. Be very careful when selecting yes
post_date: as this is a destructive process that cannot be reversed.

ID: You should then see the following prompt:
<!-- wp:code --><pre class=\"wp-block-code\"><code>OutputEnter passphrase (empty for no passphrase):
Here you optionally may enter a secure passphrase
post_author: which is highly recommended. A passphrase adds an additional layer of security to prevent unauthorized users from logging in. To learn more about security
post_date: consult our tutorial on How To Configure SSH Key-Based Authentication on a Linux Server.

ID: You should then see the following output:
<!-- wp:code --><pre class=\"wp-block-code\"><code>OutputYour identification has been saved in /your_home/.ssh/id_rsa.
Your public key has been saved in /your_home/.ssh/id_rsa.pub.
You now have a public and private key that you can use to authenticate. The next step is to place the public key on your server so that you can use SSH-key-based authentication to log in.
Step 2 — Copy the Public Key to Ubuntu Server
The quickest way to copy your public key to the Ubuntu host is to use a utility called ssh-copy-id. Due to its simplicity
post_author: this method is highly recommended if available. If you do not have ssh-copy-idavailable to you on your client machine
post_date: you may use one of the two alternate methods provided in this section (copying via password-based SSH

ID: The ssh-copy-id tool is included by default in many operating systems
post_author: so you may have it available on your local system. For this method to work
post_date: you must already have password-based SSH access to your server.

post_author: you simply need to specify the remote host that you would like to connect to and the user account that you have password SSH access to. This is the account to which your public SSH key will be copied.

ID: You may see the following message:
<!-- wp:code --><pre class=\"wp-block-code\"><code>OutputThe authenticity of host '203.0.113.1 (203.0.113.1)' can't be established.
Are you sure you want to continue connecting (yes/no)? yes
This means that your local computer does not recognize the remote host. This will happen the first time you connect to a new host. Type \"yes\" and press ENTER to continue.

post_author: the utility will scan your local account for the id_rsa.pub key that we created earlier. When it finds the key
post_date: it will prompt you for the password of the remote user's account:

ID: <!-- wp:code --><pre class=\"wp-block-code\"><code>Output/usr/bin/ssh-copy-id: INFO: attempting to log in with the new key(s)
post_author: to filter out any that are already installed

ID: /usr/bin/ssh-copy-id: INFO: 1 key(s) remain to be installed -- if you are prompted now it is to install the new keys

Type in the password (your typing will not be displayed for security purposes) and press ENTER. The utility will connect to the account on the remote host using the password you provided. It will then copy the contents of your ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub key into a file in the remote account's home ~/.ssh directory called authorized_keys.
You should see the following output:
Now try logging into the machine
post_author: with:   \"ssh 'username@203.0.113.1'\"

ID: and check to make sure that only the key(s) you wanted were added.

post_author: your id_rsa.pub key has been uploaded to the remote account. You can continue on to Step 3.

ID: If you do not have ssh-copy-id available
post_author: but you have password-based SSH access to an account on your server
post_date: you can upload your keys using a conventional SSH method.

ID: We can do this by using the cat command to read the contents of the public SSH key on our local computer and piping that through an SSH connection to the remote server.

post_author: we can make sure that the ~/.ssh directory exists and has the correct permissions under the account we’re using.

ID: We can then output the content we piped over into a file called authorized_keys within this directory. We’ll use the >> redirect symbol to append the content instead of overwriting it. This will let us add keys without destroying previously added keys.
The full command looks like this:

<!-- wp:preformatted --><pre class=\"wp-block-preformatted\">cat ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub | ssh username@remote_host \"mkdir -p ~/.ssh && touch ~/.ssh/authorized_keys && chmod -R go= ~/.ssh && cat >> ~/.ssh/authorized_keys\"
You may see the following message:
<!-- wp:code --><pre class=\"wp-block-code\"><code>OutputThe authenticity of host '203.0.113.1 (203.0.113.1)' can't be established.
Are you sure you want to continue connecting (yes/no)? yes
This means that your local computer does not recognize the remote host. This will happen the first time you connect to a new host. Type \"yes\" and press ENTER to continue.

post_author: you should be prompted to enter the remote user account password:
the content of your id_rsa.pub key will be copied to the end of the authorized_keys file of the remote user's account. Continue on to Step 3 if this was successful.

ID: If you do not have password-based SSH access to your server available
post_author: you will have to complete the above process manually.

ID: We will manually append the content of your id_rsa.pub file to the ~/.ssh/authorized_keys file on your remote machine.
To display the content of your id_rsa.pub key
post_author: type this into your local computer:

ID: You will see the key's content
post_author: which should look something like this:

ID: Access your remote host using whichever method you have available.
Once you have access to your account on the remote server
post_author: you should make sure the ~/.ssh directory exists. This command will create the directory if necessary
post_date: or do nothing if it already exists:

post_author: you can create or modify the authorized_keys file within this directory. You can add the contents of your id_rsa.pub file to the end of the authorized_keys file
post_date: creating it if necessary

post_author: substitute the public_key_string with the output from the cat ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub command that you executed on your local system. It should start with ssh-rsa AAAA....
we’ll ensure that the ~/.ssh directory and authorized_keys file have the appropriate permissions set:

ID: This recursively removes all “group” and “other” permissions for the ~/.ssh/ directory.
If you’re using the root account to set up keys for a user account
post_author: it’s also important that the ~/.sshdirectory belongs to the user and not to root:

ID: In this tutorial our user is named sammy but you should substitute the appropriate username into the above command.
We can now attempt passwordless authentication with our Ubuntu server.
Step 3 — Authenticate to Ubuntu Server Using SSH Keys
If you have successfully completed one of the procedures above
post_author: you should be able to log into the remote host without the remote account's password.

ID: The basic process is the same:
If this is your first time connecting to this host (if you used the last method above)
post_author: you may see something like this:

ID: <!-- wp:code --><pre class=\"wp-block-code\"><code>OutputThe authenticity of host '203.0.113.1 (203.0.113.1)' can't be established.
Are you sure you want to continue connecting (yes/no)? yes
This means that your local computer does not recognize the remote host. Type \"yes\" and then press ENTER to continue.
If you did not supply a passphrase for your private key
post_author: you will be logged in immediately. If you supplied a passphrase for the private key when you created the key
post_date: you will be prompted to enter it now (note that your keystrokes will not display in the terminal session for security). After authenticating
post_date_gmt: a new shell session should open for you with the configured account on the Ubuntu server.

post_author: continue on to learn how to further secure your system by disabling password authentication.

ID: Step 4 — Disable Password Authentication on your Server
If you were able to log into your account using SSH without a password
post_author: you have successfully configured SSH-key-based authentication to your account. However
post_date: your password-based authentication mechanism is still active
post_date_gmt: meaning that your server is still exposed to brute-force attacks.

ID: Before completing the steps in this section
post_author: make sure that you either have SSH-key-based authentication configured for the root account on this server
post_date: or preferably
post_date_gmt: that you have SSH-key-based authentication configured for a non-root account on this server with sudo privileges. This step will lock down password-based logins
post_content: so ensuring that you will still be able to get administrative access is crucial.

ID: Once you've confirmed that your remote account has administrative privileges
post_author: log into your remote server with SSH keys
post_date: either as root or with an account with sudo privileges. Then
post_date_gmt: open up the SSH daemon's configuration file:

post_author: search for a directive called PasswordAuthentication. This may be commented out. Uncomment the line and set the value to \"no\". This will disable your ability to log in via SSH using account passwords:/etc/ssh/sshd_config

ID: Save and close the file when you are finished by pressing CTRL + X
post_author: then Y to confirm saving the file
post_date: and finally ENTER to exit nano. To actually implement these changes

post_author: open up a new terminal window and test that the SSH service is functioning correctly before closing this session:

ID: Once you have verified your SSH service
post_author: you can safely close all current server sessions.

ID: The SSH daemon on your Ubuntu server now only responds to SSH keys. Password-based authentication has successfully been disabled.
You should now have SSH-key-based authentication configured on your server
post_author: allowing you to sign in without providing an account password.

ID: If you'd like to learn more about working with SSH
post_author:
take a look at our SSH Essentials Guide.

post_date: How To Set Up SSH Keys on Ubuntu 16.04
post_date_gmt:
SSH, or secure shell, is an encrypted protocol used to administer and communicate with servers. When working with an Ubuntu server, chances are you will spend most of your time in a terminal session connected to your server through SSH.

In this guide, we'll focus on setting up SSH keys for a vanilla Ubuntu 16.04 installation. SSH keys provide an easy, secure way of logging into your server and are recommended for all users

It's one of life's great mysteries.

After debating whether Snapchat is a viable marketing platform, you'll want to know how often you should be posting on social media.

As a social media manager, you want to achieve the best result from each social media post. There has to be a good time and a bad time to post, right?

In this guide, we'll answer this proverbial question so that your content can reach a wider audience.

How often should I post on social media?

Over the years I've read countless articles regarding the optimal posting frequency on social media networks. And I've reached the conclusion that they're all flawed.

One article suggests posting no more than twice a day on Facebook. The next one says you should post to LinkedIn on weekdays only, preferably between 4 pm and 6 pm.

But, in reality, there is no magic formula.

Because what works for one brand, doesn't work for another. Sure you can read case studies of what has worked for others, but don't make their solution your solution.

So, instead of seeking magic formulas, let's focus on these proven posting strategies:

  • Posting consistency is more important than posting frequency.
  • Content quality is more important than content quantity (and social media networks are letting us know with all the changes).
  • Without having an objective for social media, you won't know if your posts are successful or not.

Aim for consistency

ID: The problem with suggested posting frequencies is the skewed data. It's okay to say
post_author: \"We analyzed thousands of posts and this is what we found...\"
post_date: but this is still a 'mish-mash' of data. For instance
post_date_gmt: how does the location of you and your audience affect posting
post_content: and how do different industries react to the number of posts shared?

ID: One of the most baffling suggestions is that you should post at a specific time of day. For example:

post_author: post once a day between 1 pm and 4 pm.\"

ID: That's crazy and ambiguous. For a start
post_author: does it mean 1 pm Sydney
post_date: 1 pm London or 1 pm New York? Or does it mean the equivalent of 1 pm CST in your local time
post_content: 1 pm CST would be 7 pm GMT. That's quite relevant

ID: Imagine everyone heeded this advice and posted at 1 pm EST (New York). For 23 hours
post_author: Facebook would remain dormant before exploding with thousands of posts at the allotted time.

ID: A better alternative is to aim for posting consistency. Create a plan and stick to it.

post_author: if you decide you'll post twice a day on Facebook
post_date: you know you need to create or curate content to fill that schedule. Your audience will know that they can visit your page at any given time and expect two fresh posts every 24 hours.

ID:
The chances of your content being pushed to someone's newsfeed have been reduced following changes to the social media algorithms. You need people to start coming to you. And the best way to attract them is to have something worthwhile for them to digest.

"

post_date: How Often Should you Post? Aim to post on Instagram between one to three times per day. Major brands post on average of 1.5 times per day, so if you aim to follow the same rule you should do well. While this is a general rule to follow, it may not work best for you.

WordPress was originally built as a blogging platform, but is now what is known as a CMS – Content Management System.

Any website that you intend to make updates to can benefit from a CMS. If it’s a blog, you want to be able to add posts. If it’s a restaurant website, you want to be able to add and update menus. If it’s a company website, you want to be able to update prices, packages, and so on. This website is a custom theme running on WordPress. (Open source, too!)

If someone is paying you to make a website, it’s because they don’t know how or don’t have time to deal with code. It needs to be as simple as possible for the client. WordPress can help with all this and more.

Whether you want to promote your business, design a portfolio, or are looking for the perfect creative outlet, you may be wondering how to create a blog. Fortunately, starting a blog isn’t that complicated  

1. Find Your Niche and Decide What to Blog About

What is a niche? And why does your blog need one?

A niche is more than just a topic. It’s the approach you’re going to take, the audience you want to go after, and the way you’re going to talk to them and position yourself as an expert. A niche doesn’t have to be your passion (although it’s definitely easier to stay committed to starting your blog when you’re passionate about it). But it does have to be an interest of yours. The best niches are exciting enough that you’ll be motivated to continually post about it, and accessible enough that you can build an audience. So, whether that means Medieval history, traditional Mexican cooking, starting a drop-shipping business, or knitting tips, is up to you. The reason your blog needs a niche is that it gives it focus. Your niche is how you’ll plan your content calendar, decide on design, and know where (and how) to market your blog. It’s also how your audience will find you and how you’ll make connections with other bloggers. Remember, when you write to everyone. You’re writing to no one.  2. Pick A domain When you type Google.com (or innoxafrica.com) into your browser in order to visit a site, that’s the website’s domain name. In a nutshell, a domain name is like your address. It tells people (and web browsers) where to find your site. A good example is your home address. If you’re using a free blogging service, you'll most likely get to pick your own domain name with it. However, it will almost always have the company’s name attached to it. So, if you use something like a free Wix site to make your blog, your domain name will look like this: Yoursitename.wixsite.com Ugh. Not very nice, right? If you’re trying to build a business around your blog, or want other people to take it seriously, this isn’t a great start. Instead, when you buy an affordable domain name, you get to choose exactly what you want it to be as long as it’s available. That way, it'll look like this: Yoursitename.com  (learn more about domain  here)

ID: Much cleaner right? Head over to Bluehost and get 65% off on both your domain name and hosting plan right here on Bluehost and you'll be able to quickly search to see if your domain name idea is available—and get smart suggestions on a second best domain name if your first choice is already taken.

post_author: put yourself in your reader’s shoes.

but now it’s time to get serious. Think about your future blog's general topic area and who your ideal reader is. What do they want to read? What’s going to grab their attention? What’s going to tell them they have to read your blog?

ID: Start with a list of everything you want your blog to be about. Go deep. There are no bad ideas here.
Once you’ve got a massive list
post_author: start to look for connections and combinations that might work. Try to keep them simple and memorable.

ID: Some great blog name examples are:

post_author: say it out loud and tell it to people.

ID: It’s easy to get wrapped up in some fun wordplay when it comes to picking a blog name.
But it still needs to be easy enough that people will remember it and be able to tell their friends about you. To practice
post_author: say the name out loud and to friends and family. What do they think about it? What emotions does it bring up for them?

ID: They might not be your ideal reader
post_author: but they can still give you a good outsider’s perspective either way.

post_author: because it acts as a one-stop shop for great (affordable) hosting and quick & easy registration of your domain name in one swoop.

ID: Think of hosting like being your home. When someone comes over (types in your URL)
post_author: they’ll be able to see all the things you’ve been keeping inside. Yes
post_date: it comes at a cost you don't have if you're on one of the free blogging platforms
post_date_gmt: but having a proper website host is one of the most important investments in starting a successful blog.

post_author: Michelle Schroeder started her personal finance blog
post_date: Making Sense of Cents
post_date_gmt: she started by using a free blogging platform called Blogger to host her site. This choice ended up costing her more than she’d saved:

ID: <em>“My biggest mistake was probably starting on Blogger
post_author: because you don’t own it. At one point Google deleted my blog with no notice. I finally begged them and they gave it back to me
post_date: but that was the moment I decided to move over to self-hosted WordPress.”

ID: Michelle’s gone on to grow her blog revenue well into the millions of dollars a year—something she says never would have happened if she hadn’t switched over to a paid hosting provider.

post_author: her number one piece of advice for new bloggers is to start on a self-hosted WordPress site and use Bluehost as your host.

ID: What are the best blog hosting services?
There are tons of great website hosting services out there for your blog.
But what you should be looking for in all of them is:
The one service I’ve found that checks all of these boxes (and more) for just getting started is Bluehost. Yes
post_author: I know I’ve mentioned them several times already in this guide
post_date: and that’s for very good reason.

post_author: Bluehost offers an incredibly simple 1-click WordPress install

ID: which makes starting a self-hosted WordPress blog super easy. It also comes with a free domain name (if your desired URL is available) and offers 24/7 support to answer all of your questions and help with troubleshooting (which is fantastic when you’re just getting started).
There are other CMS <em>(A Content Management System (or CMS) is where you'll be writing
post_author: designing
post_date: and publishing your blog posts. A good CMS is easy to use
post_content: upload images and videos
post_title: and have control over how your entire blog looks using themes or custom design elements.) options you can look at
comment_status: and Wix when learning how to start a blog. However
ping_status: I strongly recommend setting up a self-hosted WordPress site for your blog as it’s the most sustainable
post_password: long-term solution—and really the only option worth considering if you're starting a blog with the eventual goal of making money from your website in some way

ID: Since I learned how to start a blog
post_author: I’ve been running my blog on WordPress (hosted with Bluehost for the first few years) and I couldn’t be happier with the amount of flexibility
post_date: control and long-term growth potential I have over my site.

post_author: one thing you need to be careful of is that WordPress comes in two very different platforms. WordPress.com and WordPress.org. They have almost the same name
post_date: but there are very big differences between the two.

ID: Picking a blog theme can be a lot of fun. But it can also take up a ton of time that you could otherwise be using to write and promote your posts (and thus getting to your first blog income faster).
There are so many themes to check out
post_author: that it’s easy to get swept away by the ones that look awesome
post_date: but might not be functionally great.

post_author: design isn’t just about how your blog looks. It’s about how it works. And the easier it is to navigate and read
post_date: the better.

ID: Here are a few suggestions of what to look for when checking out themes:
• Keep it simple: At the end of the day
post_author: the goal of starting a blog is to share content that can be easily consumed (read
post_date: watched
post_content: a lot of fancy blog themes get in the way of that. Don’t get too drawn in by crazy looking themes that compromise on legibility and usability. If a theme looks good
post_title: but doesn’t help you share your thoughts and engage with readers

ID: • Responsiveness is a must: Responsiveness refers to themes that make sure your blog looks as good on a laptop
post_author: as it does on someone’s smartphone. Today
post_date: more and more people use their phones to read blogs and depending on your audience
post_date_gmt: that number could be 50% or higher (like mine is). Google also favors mobile-friendly websites and ranks them at the top of their organic search results. If you’re not totally sure whether a theme is mobile friendly or not
post_content: copy and paste the URL of the theme’s demo page into Google’s Mobile Friendly Test page. (This test will almost always show some warnings. But major red flags to watch out for are text too small or content wider than screen.)

ID: • Does it work in different browsers? Your readers won’t just be using different devices
post_author: but different browsers. Most theme developers rigorously test their themes across browsers
post_date: but sometimes mistakes slip through. Try testing on a couple different browsers just to make sure.

post_author: the real power of your blog comes from plugins. These are “Add-ons” to your blog that give you extra functionality. Make sure the theme you’re choosing supports all popular plugins. If you’re unsure
post_date: ask the developer.

post_author: or search engine optimization
post_date: refers to how well Google and other search engines can find your information when people search for it. Some themes use bulky code that makes it difficult for search engines to read. And while no one expects you to inspect a theme’s code you should see if the developer has said it is optimized for SEO.

ID: • Support: Problems happen. And when they do
post_author: you want to be able to ask for help. Lots of free theme developers won’t offer support for their products. So that’s one thing to be aware of when making your choice.

ID: • Ratings and reviews: Look for themes with a good track record. If the theme is sold on a third-party marketplace you should be able to see reviews no problem. For free WordPress theme
post_author: you’ll see the ratings just below the download button.

ID: Your WordPress site is made up of Posts and Pages.
Posts are what we commonly think about when we think of a blog. These are individual articles on specific topics. For example
post_author: if you have a recipe blog
post_date: you might have posts like “The Best Chocolate Chip Cookies
post_date_gmt: ” “Rosemary Meat Loaf” and “Raspberry Lemonade.” Each post would feature one recipe.

ID: When we talk about adding new content to our blogs
post_author: we are usually referring to publishing a new post. And when we scroll through a blog
post_date: we are usually scrolling through the posts.

post_author: on the other hand
post_date: contain more permanent or unchanging information. Pages don’t show up in the blog portion of the site alongside the posts. Instead
post_date_gmt: they are usually accessed through direct links in the the navigation bar
post_content: sidebar or footer.

ID: Some Pages are common on all blogs
post_author: like a contact page and an about page
post_date: but some bloggers include other pages as well.

post_author: otherwise you may break your link!)
post_date: check and edit the permalink if you’d like.

ID: Use keywords and make it as close to the way someone would search for your content on Google.
If you want to change the permalink structure of a post or page
post_author: simply click the “Edit” button next to the automatically generated permalink on your post or page and change it to what you want.

ID: 7. Create Essential Pages And Publish Your First Page.
Every blog needs to showcase some basic
post_author: foundational information. Who you are. Why people should listen to you. How they can get in touch with you if they have questions or want to work with you.
