post_author: it is often the case that you will have a number of small programs that you want to run persistently
post_date: whether these be small shell scripts
post_content: or any large-sized packages.

post_author: you may write a init script for each of these programs
post_date: but this can quickly become time consuming to manage and isn't always particularly transparent for newer users.

ID: Supervisor is a process manager which makes managing a number of long-running programs a trivial task by providing a consistent interface through which they can be monitored and controlled.
This tutorial assumes that you are familiar with the command line
post_author: installing packages
post_date: and basic server management.

ID: Installation of Supervisor on both Ubuntu and Debian is incredibly simple
post_author: as prebuilt packages already exist within both distributions' repositories.
run the following command to install the Supervisor package:
the supervisor daemon should already be started
post_date: as the prebuilt packages come with an init script that will also ensure the Supervisor is restarted after a system reboot. You can ensure this is the case by running:

post_author: we can look at adding our first programs.

ID: New programs are given to Supervisor through configuration files
post_author: which inform it of the executable to run
post_date: any environmental variables
post_date_gmt: and how output should be handled.

ID: Note: All programs run under Supervisor must be run in a non-daemonising mode (sometimes also called 'foreground mode'). If
post_author: by default
post_date: the program forks and returns on startup
post_date_gmt: then you may need to consult the program's manual to find the option to enable this mode
post_content: otherwise Supervisor will not be able to properly determine the status of the program.

post_author: we'll assume we have a shell script we wish to keep persistently running that we have saved at /usr/local/bin/long.sh and looks like the following:
this script is clearly rather pointless
post_date: but it will allow us to cover the fundamentals of Supervisor configuration.

ID: The program configuration files for Supervisor programs are found in the /etc/supervisor/conf.d directory
post_author: normally with one program per file and a .conf extension. A simple configuration for our script
post_date: saved at /etc/supervisor/conf.d/long_script.conf

ID: We'll look at the significance of each line and some of the tweaks that may be desirable for your program below:
The configuration begins by defining a program with the name 'long_script' and the full path to the program:
The next two lines define the basic automatic behaviour of the script under certain conditions.
The autostart option tells Supervisor that this program should be started when the system boots. Setting this to false will require a manual start command following any system shutdown.
autorestart defines how Supervisor should manage the program in the event it exits and has three options:

• false' tells Supervisor not to ever restart the program after it exits
  • 'true' tells Supervisor to always restart the program after it exits
  • 'unexpected' tells Supervisor to only restart the program if it exits with an unexpected error code (by default anything other than codes 0 or 2).
The final two lines define the locations of the two main log files for the program. As suggested by the option names
post_author: stdout and stderr will be directed to the stdout_logfile and stderr_logfile locations respectively. The specified directory specified must exist before we start the program
post_date: as Supervisor will not attempt to create any missing directories.

ID: The configuration we have created here is a minimal reasonable template for a Supervisor program. The documentation lists many more optional configuration options that are available to fine tune how the program is executed.
Once our configuration file is created and saved
post_author: we can inform Supervisor of our new program through the supervisorctl command. First we tell Supervisor to look for any new or changed program configurations in the /etc/supervisor/conf.d directory with:

ID: Followed by telling it to enact any changes with:
Any time you make a change to any program configuration file
post_author: running the two previous commands will bring the changes into effect.

ID: At this point our program should now be running and we can check this is the case by looking at the output log file:

post_author: there will undoubtedly be a time when we want to stop
post_date: restart
post_date_gmt: or see their status. The supervisorctl program
post_content: which we first used above
post_title: also has an interactive mode through which we can issue commands to control our programs.

post_author: start supervisorctl with no arguments:
uptime 1:49:37
supervisorctl will initially print the status and uptime of all programs
post_date: followed by showing a command prompt. Entering help will reveal all of the available commands that we can use:

ID: add    clear  fg        open  quit    remove  restart   start   stop  update
avail  exit   maintail  pid   reload  reread  shutdown  status  tail  version

post_author: we can start
post_date: stop and restart a program with the associated commands followed by the program name:

post_author: we can view the most recent entries in the stdout and stderr logs for our program:

ID: Using status we can view again the current execution state of each program after making any changes:

post_author: once we are finished
post_date: we can exit supervisorctl with Ctrl-C or by entering quit into the prompt:

ID: And that's it! You've mastered the basics of managing persistent programs through Supervisor and extending this to your own programs should be a relatively simple task. If you have any questions or further advice
post_author: be sure to leave it in the comments section.

If you don’t have a very strong website
post_author: you can target longer tail keywords (<50 searches a month) which are often much easier to rank for. From this you can start building up a base of content that you can then use to earn links and propel rankings for more competitive terms.

post_author: Reddit

post_date_gmt: and I’ve seen Reddit drive tens of thousands of visits to sites.

post_date: will let people subscribe to replies to their comments that they leave on your content. You can also use a myriad of tools (like SumoMe) to capture email addresses to which you can send content when it publishes.

ID: If you’ve had someone sign up to your product
post_author: email them when something happens (a product goes out of stock or comes in stock
post_date: metrics change
post_date_gmt: etc) to get them back to engage with your product again.

ID: Email users who abandon their shopping cart
If you run an ecommerce site
post_author: email them when they’ve left something that they wanted to buy.

ID: If you run a site that has products or things directly for sale
post_author: you could consider an affiliate program. While affiliate programs take management
post_date: they are also a great way to get others to talk about your products for free and you only pay if they buy something.

post_author: partnerships can be a great way to drive relevant traffic that is ready to convert to your site. This has been a major way Credo has grown. Begin with outreach to sites that have written roundups of alternatives for your competitors and see if they’d like to include your site. Bonus points for getting them to add you at the top.

ID: 2018 was the year of influencer marketing
post_author: and this will only continue into  2019. Get influencers to post about your products
post_date: blog on your site and share it
post_date_gmt: or interview them and provide it for free to your users."
post_content: 51 Ways to drive traffic to your website in Kenya
post_title:
You need more website traffic. If you run an online business, traffic is your lifeblood because it enables your business model to work and pay your bills. Therefore, you need to employee multiple strategies to bring new visitors to your site and keep old visitors engaged with your content.

Here are 51 ways to drive and increase traffic to your website in 2019.

For the project I’m working on we use GitHub. Recently new satellite app was developed by an external team
post_title: and this team uses Bitbucket. It would be nice to have sources synchronized to our GitHub organization so we can have a central place for all of it.

ID: Repo mirroring can be accomplished using Bitbucket pipelines. It is relatively easy to set up mirroring using SSH key profiled as deployment key with write access on GitHub.
<li id=\"9ce7\" class=\"he hf fo hg b hh id hi hj hk ie hl hm hn if ho hp hq ig hr hs ht ih hu hv hx ii ij ik gk\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">On GitHub
post_author: create new repository.

ID: <li id=\"a806\" class=\"he hf fo hg b hh il hi hj hk im hl hm hn in ho hp hq io hr hs ht ip hu hv hx ii ij ik gk\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">In Bitbucket repository
post_author: create bitbucket-pipelines.yml as following:

ID: <pre class=\"iq ir is it iu iv iw ix\"><span id=\"3bc4\" class=\"gk iy iz fo ic b do ja jb s jc\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">clone:
- git push --mirror git@github.com:YourOrg/mirror-repo.git
• Commit pipeline file. This will run pipeline and fail (yet).
<li id=\"cbdf\" class=\"he hf fo hg b hh il hi hj hk im hl hm hn in ho hp hq io hr hs ht ip hu hv hx ii ij ik gk\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">On Bitbucket
post_author: go to the repository’s Settings / SSH keys and generate a new SSH key. Copy resulting public key to clipboard.

ID: • In Known Hosts section on the same page enter github.com and click fetch and then add host.
<li id=\"0b73\" class=\"he hf fo hg b hh il hi hj hk im hl hm hn in ho hp hq io hr hs ht ip hu hv hx ii ij ik gk\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">On GitHub
post_author: in repository settings add a deployment key (Settings / Deploy Keys) granting write permission
post_date: and add the public key generated in Bitbucket.

ID: • Now on Bitbucket go to pipelines and re-run failed sync pipeline. This time it should succeed.

Now on every push BitBucket will mirror changes to your repo.

"
post_author: Mirror (SYNC) Bitbucket Repository to GitHub Repository.
